properties.description:
In this image, there are three men on the plain, and the Jihun river surrounds them. The man who wears in red is Gurwi, he is cutting the man’s neck who wears in green. His name is Siyavush. Then a soldier-like man villain Garsiwaz uses a golden basin to take Siyavush’s blood. This picture’s background is about the second part of the Epic of Siyavush.

Siyavush, who is a major figure in Ferdowsi's epic, the Shahnameh, is a young man well-versed in the arts of war. He has a good reputation but is framed by his stepmother. Hence Siavash finds no alternative but to go into self-imposed exile in the mythical land of Turan, and seek shelter under the rule of Afrasiab, the tyrannical arch-enemy of the Iranian Shah. However, Afrasiab is cruel and he is also jealous of Siyavush’s reputation. After helping his wife escape, Siyavush is dragged before Afrasiab, who orders his execution by beheading. The hot-headed Afrasiab ignores others’ warnings and executes Siyavush. As Siyavush's blood reaches the ground, a plant grows upon the same spot and is later named 'Khune Asyavushan,' or the 'blood of Siyavush.' Siavash is the symbol of innocence in Iranian literature. The defense of his own chastity, self-imposed exile, constancy in love for his wife, and ultimate execution at the hands of his adopted host have become intertwined with Iranian mythology and literature over the past millennia. In Iranian mythology, his name is also linked with the growth of plants.

Here the ringleader Garsiwaz has ordered Gurwi to murder Siyavush.Garsiwaz glanced at Gurwi; then the villain turns round and goes up to Siyawush, showing no observance and humanity. He grasps the prince's beard with his hand, to drag him through the dust.

Gurwi is in red, under the red coat, he is lined with orange clothes. He wears a hat with two points, and the top of this hat is arched. Then he receives a blue-steel dagger from Garsiwaz for the bloody deed.

Gurwi drags Siyavush out into the plain by his hair afoot and does not behead him until they come to where the marker has stood.

When he tries to kill Siyavush, Gurwi seizes Siyavush’s hair and rides on his back. Villain Gurwi’s eyebrows are furrowed and his mouth slightly opens in a fierce expression. He turns up the prince’s face as a‘twere a sheep’s’, cuts off the sliver Cypross’ head, and allows his blood to run into a bowl.

Then Gurwi takes up the bowl and empties it where he has been commanded. From that blood presently there sprang a plant, which name is 'blood of Siyavush.'

When the Sun had left the Cypress-stem, the prince's head had fallen asleep.
"...to the Water Works, a distance of about ten miles, on the river front;"
"...and from the Insane Asylum on the southwest... "

"...to the Cemeteries on the northwest. Every foot of the vast territory within these limits has been carefully examined and topographically drawn in perspective, by Mr. C. N. Dry and his assistants, and the faithfulness and accuracy with which this work has been done an examination of the pages will attest. Absolute truth and accuracy in the representation of the territory has been the standard and in no cases have additions or alterations been made unless the same were actually in course of construction. In a few cases, important public and private edifices that are not yet finished are shown completed, and as they will appear when done. All the buildings within the limits of the survey in July, 1875, are shown; and a very large number of those executed or commenced since that date have been also introduced, the pages having been constantly corrected up to the last possible moment before publication."

"In dividing the work into pages, it will be seen that in, cases where a building is but partially drawn on one page, it is given complete on the adjoining page. In view of the magnitude of the work, the originality of the idea, and the difficulties encountered in carrying it out, it is hoped that if any mistakes or errors have crept into the plates or pages, they will be looked upon with a lenient eye by an indulgent public." (Dry & Compton)
